events.title: The 49th session of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (ECE) Working Party on Inland Water Transport was held in Geneva from 18 to 20 October 2005

paragraphs.text: The working group of the Belarusian delegation led by the permanent deputy of the Republic of Belarus in Geneva Andrei Savinykh. Participants of the session considered the trends of development of inland water transport of the member countries, discussed measures aimed at stimulating the traffic on inland waterways. Particular attention was paid to the prospects for the development of water transport infrastructure.

Andrei Savinykh made a presentation on the prospects for the construction of the Dnipro-Vysla-Oder water transport connection. According to the Belarusian delegation, the development of trade between the East and the West insists on the restoration of the water union. The volume of transportation on the route 'Dnepr - Vistula-Oder' can make about 3 million tons of cargo per year. Of particular importance, this route may have for the transportation of bulk goods (coal, ores, gravel, cement, metal products, etc.) towards Germany and the Scandinavian countries, as its length is 885 kilometers shorter than the traditional route of delivery by water the Danube-Main-Rhine. By the waterways of this transport connection, various tourist routes can also be laid.

Having considered the arguments of the Belarusian side, the Working Group supported the proposal for a comprehensive economic and environmental assessment of the Dnipro-Vysla-Oder water union and the establishment of a Rapporteurs Group for the preparation of documents for this project within the framework of the UNECE Inland Transport Committee. For the question from our country further answered the head of the department of foreign economic activity of the Ministry of Transport and Communications of Belarus Sergey Negrei.

events.title: signing contract with the winning bidder - international consortium headed by Maritime institute, Gdansk

paragraphs.text: Results: as a result of the meeting three scenarios of the E40 reconstruction which involve creation of a flume connection Poland and Belarus are approved - all the scenarios concern exclusively the territory of Poland.

events.title: Consortium of development of <abbr title='feasibility study'>FS</abbr> performs on its first progress made

paragraphs.text: Results: a proirity way of reconstruction of shipping along the whole length of the E40 has been determinated. According to the plan a flume of about 160 kilometers will be constructed on Polish territory, as well as modernisation and construction of water-control facilities on Visla, Dnieper, Pripyat and Dnieper-Bug canal will be conducted. Total price of the project amounts to about €12 bln of which €12 is work on Polish territory, €96,2-171,2 mln in Belarus and €31mln in Ukraine.

events.title: second session of the Cross-border Comission

paragraphs.text: Results: according to ecologists there is a necessity to study more carefully the issue of how reconstruction and utilization of the E40 waterway will influence the water conditions and biodiversity of rivers producing it: Visla, Western Bug, Pripyat and Dnieper, along which a huge amount of natural territories, including those of international significance, are located.

events.title: Environmental forum which presents the results of the consortium work and where potential risks for the environment are discussed

paragraphs.text: Results: adoption of resolution in which certain points urge to conduct environment impact assessment (EIA) for the whole E40 and present actions on restricting negative environmental impact.

events.title: <mark>start of Stop E40 public campaign</mark> initiated by BirdLife Belarus, Bahna, Ecohome, Environmental Solutions Centre and Green Network
The Belarus environmental alliance has sent an appeal against the projected E40 waterway to the European Union and other international organizations

paragraphs.text: The environmentalists are urging the organizations to support a petition to terminate the project, which would connect the Baltic and the Black Sea. The appeal was sent on behalf of forty-two non-governmental organisations and a number of local residents from three nations: Belarus, Ukraine and Poland. Online petitions have been signed by 5,910 Belarusians and Ukrainians, and by 23,371 Poles.

The defenders of the Pripyat River invite investors’ attention to highly adverse consequences of E40 project implementation and call for ultimate abandonment of plans to fund the project. The appeal was sent to the governments of three countries, the European Parliament, the Secretariats of the Århus and Espoo Conventions, and to several investment banks.
